channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri, a 36-year-old artist from Siberia, took three days to get by bus and train to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, where he now lives in a 20-bed hostel room.

item.title: Ukraine Expels Some Russian Troops in South
item.description: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops moving through the recently recaptured village of Yatskivka on Tuesday. Ukraine has recaptured cities in the northeast, the east and now the south.

item.title: US National Debt Tops $31 Trillion for First Time
item.description: America’s borrowing binge has long been viewed as sustainable because of historically low interest rates. But as rates rise, the nation’s fiscal woes are getting worse.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has pledged to bring down federal budget deficits by $1 trillion over a decade.

item.title: Elon Musk Suggests Buying Twitter at His Original Price
item.description: The billionaire’s surprise move came months after he tried to back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Lauren Hirsch and Andrew Ross Sorkin
item.media:description: Elon Musk, center, has agreed to acquire Twitter at $54.20 per share, according to filings made public on Tuesday.

item.title: Aaron Judge Hits Homer 62, Passing Roger Maris for AL Record
item.description: A blast against Texas vaulted Judge past Roger Maris for the American League’s single-season record, rekindling enthusiasm for a milestone spoiled by the steroid era.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Nathan Hunsinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: With a 391-foot blast against the Texas Rangers on Tuesday, Aaron Judge of the Yankees reached 62 home runs for the season, setting a new single-season American League record.

item.title: In Speedy Embrace of Herschel Walker, Republicans Make Familiar Political Bargain
item.description: While the Georgia Senate candidate denied a report that he paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, his Republican allies looked past the claims toward November.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Maya King and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Republican leaders signaled on Tuesday that they planned to stand by Herschel Walker after a report that he had paid for a girlfriend’s abortion in 2009.

item.title: Loretta Lynn, Country Music Star and Symbol of Rural Resilience, Dies at 90
item.description: Her powerful voice, playful lyrics and topical songs were a model for generations of country singers and songwriters. So was her life story.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
item.category: You Ain't Woman Enough (to Take My Man) (Song)

item.title: Loretta Lynn Didn’t Pretty Things Up
item.description: The country star sang about desire, cheating, heartache and righteous revenge in three-minute vignettes that depicted lives she knew and understood.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Kyle Dean Reinford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loretta Lynn created an archetype that spoke to the heart of country music and reached far beyond it.

item.title: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Intervene in Review of Mar-a-Lago Records
item.description: In earlier cases, the justices have ruled against the former president when he sought to shield his financial and presidential records from prosecutors and congressional investigators.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump appealed on narrow grounds, not asking the Supreme Court to overturn the most important part of an appeals court’s decision.

item.title: Supreme Court Leans Toward Alabama in Voting Rights Dispute
item.description: But several members of the court’s conservative majority rejected the state’s most aggressive arguments in defense of its congressional voting map.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Mickey Welsh/The Montgomery Advertiser, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The case before the Supreme Court concerned a congressional map drawn by Alabama lawmakers that a lower court had said diluted the power of Black voters.

item.title: After the Storm, the Mold: Warming Is Worsening Another Costly Disaster
item.description: Mold in homes is a costly crisis that often accompanies hurricanes and flooding, and climate change is amplifying the rain that feeds outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin and Emily Kask
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: Florida’s GOP Leaders Opposed Climate Aid. Now They’re Depending on It.
item.description: Senior Republican politicians in the state have opposed federal action against global warming, which is making storms like Hurricane Ian more destructive.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.

item.title: Oath Keepers Texts Provide Window Into Conspiracy Mind-set
item.description: Texts and social media posts introduced at the seditious conspiracy trial of Stewart Rhodes and four other members of the far-right militia show fear, aggression and apparent self-delusion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Stewart Rhodes, founder of the militia group known as the Oath Keepers, speaking at a rally outside the White House in 2017. Texts featured at his trial paint a portrait of an organization in thrall to conspiracy theories.

item.title: Abuse in Women’s Soccer Left Players With Nowhere To Turn
item.description: A report on dysfunction in women’s soccer showed that abuse of players in the National Women’s Soccer League was “an open secret.” Players had nowhere to turn.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter

item.title: Portland and Chicago Owners Step Aside as U.S. Soccer Stars Call for Change
item.description: Becky Sauerbrunn said any official found to have failed to protect players “should be gone.” As she spoke, the owner of her club, the Portland Thorns, said he would leave the team temporarily. Chicago’s shortly followed suit.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das and Kevin Draper
item.category: United States Women's National Soccer Team
item.media:description: The United States captain Becky Sauerbrunn, who is a member of the National Women’s Soccer League’s Portland Thorns.

item.title: Unearthing Everyday Life at an Ancient Site in Greece
item.description: Excavations in the Peloponnesian village of Iklaina are yielding rich insights into the lives of the Mycenaean civilization’s general population.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stirn
item.media:description: An archaeologist carefully unearths a pottery fragment.

item.title: The First Global Deflation Has Begun, and It’s Unclear Just How Painful It Will Be
item.description: We now find ourselves in the midst of the most comprehensive tightening of monetary policy the world has seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Tooze
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images via Getty Images

item.title: What a Conservative Therapist Thinks About U.S. Politics and Mental Health
item.description: Conservatives need mental health help, too, but do they need to get it from someone who shares their worldview?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Daum
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times

item.title: The Deadly Collision of Racism and Mental Illness
item.description: How can we talk honestly about when mentally ill people commit hate crimes?
item.dc:creator: Eyal Press
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mike McQuade. Photograph by Getty Images/EyeEm Premium

item.title: The Failed Quest for Community Mental Health Centers in the U.S.
item.description: America has neglected people with serious mental illnesses for far too long.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Animation by Xander Opiyo. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: To Save America’s Coasts, Don’t Always Rebuild Them
item.description: Taxpayers too often subsidize irresponsible development, with tragic results.
item.dc:creator: Robert S. Young
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., after it was hit by Hurricane Ian last Friday.

item.title: The Supreme Court Seems Awfully Nervous About Its Own Legitimacy
item.description: If justice after justice finds it necessary to defend the court’s power, what does that tell you?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Sarah van Rij for The New York Times

item.title: Interrogating the Stories We Tell About Our Minds
item.description: The journalist Rachel Aviv complicates narratives surrounding mental illness.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.category: Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us (Book)

item.title: Boys and Men Are in Crisis Because Society Is
item.description: A new book has the right diagnosis, but its solutions are too small.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It (Book)
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times

item.title: Where defending nature can be deadly
item.description: No region is more dangerous for environmentalists than Latin America. We explain why it’s getting worse.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Indigenous land defenders detained a logger in Brazil, by many measures the world’s most dangerous country for environmental activists, in 2019.

item.title: Poll Update: Republicans Gain in the Senate
item.description: A closer look at Pennsylvania and Nevada, and some Democratic leads that seem vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:description: John Fetterman, the Democratic Senate candidate in Pennsylvania, has seen his lead in the polls dwindle, perhaps because Republican voters are coming home to their party.

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: One Last Haircut
item.description: A man comes out to his wife — and breaks apart their family. Fifteen years later, we check back in.

item.title: Scary Stories
item.description: It’s Spooky Season. What are your favorite scary books, movies, TV shows and podcasts?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Economists Nervously Eye the Bank of England’s Market Rescue
item.description: The Bank of England stepped in to save a critical market this week. Economists say it was necessary but also worry about the precedent.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
item.media:description: The Bank of England turned to mass bond purchases to calm markets last week.

item.title: Police Say a Serial Killer Could Be Behind Shootings in Stockton, Calif.
item.description: The police said they had connected a series of shootings that have left six dead through ballistics and video footage and said a serial killer could be to blame.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor, Michael Levenson and Eduardo Medina

item.title: Tear Gas, a Stampede, and an Indonesian Family Shattered
item.description: Muhammad Yulianto and Devi Ratna Sari took their young son to his first soccer match. The young couple were among the 125 who died in the tragedy at the Indonesian stadium.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Muhammad Alfiansyah, 11, with photographs of his parents, in Malang on Tuesday.

item.title: These Job-Training Programs Work, and May Show Others the Way
item.description: A handful of innovators have developed successful programs to help lift low-income workers into the middle class. Can their model become the norm?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Alyssa Pointer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amber Mitchell Ikpe, a technology database manager in Georgia, says Year Up’s program helped her start a career in technology.

item.title: Your Medical Test Results Are Available. But Do You Want to View Them?
item.description: The 21st Century Cures Act gave patients easy access to their health information. Now, some diagnoses delivered without context are causing high anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman

item.title: Is Teeth Whitening Safe? What to Know and Products to Use
item.description: Many products claim to lighten and brighten your teeth. Here’s what the experts say about them.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Ryan Jenq for The New York Times. Prop Stylist: Laura Woolf

item.title: How To Make Friends As An Adult
item.description: A friendship expert shares strategies for finding connection in a lonely, disconnected world.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Platonic: How the Science of Attachment Can Help You Make -- and Keep -- Friends (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Vanessa Saba; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: How to Give Constructive Feedback
item.description: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Pain in Children is Often Ignored. For Children of Color, It’s Even Worse.
item.description: Racial differences in medical care are part of a theme experts are seeing “over and over” again.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman

item.title: In ‘Smile,’ Why the Grins Are So Grim
item.description: Parker Finn, the director of the new horror film where characters smile before death, said the secret to making a smile creepy was in the eyes.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
